Name: David D
Title: A sprawling fort complex with shops, museums, and palaces from the time of the Mughals.
Review: The Red Fort of Delhi is a very large fort in Old Delhi. It can be entered from the Lahore Gate and there are shops on the entranceway in. The palaces are preserved, but have clearly been looted over the centuries. For those with an interest in history, the museum of the First War of Independence is worth checking also. Definitely worth a visit if in Delhi.

Name: Surya Katakam
Title: Original Fort was in white color
Review: Red fort which is also famous as Lal Quila is spread across 255 acres in Old Delhi city and become one of the land mark location of the city. Nearest Metro station to Red fort is Chandni chowk station. There are two gates to enter inside one is called as Delhi gate and another one is called as Lahori gate. Delhi Gate is located on the southern wall of the Red fort and Lahori Gate is located on the Western wall. Red fort is recognized as a UNESCO world heritage Site in the year 2007. Red fort was the residence of Mughal emperors for 200 years and after that it was taken over by the Britishers. Bahadur Shah Zafar was the last Mughal Emperor who was coronated here in the year 1837. Architecture:Shah Jahan decided to shift capital of Mughal Empire from Agra to Delhi by the side of River Yamuna. Architect Ustad Ahmad Lahauri was then assigned the task of building the Red fort. Architecture is made in Mughal and Indo-Islamic style. Red fort construction was started on 12th May 1638 and completed on 16th April 1648. It was Emperor Shah Jahan who built Red Fort. Red fort was actually white in color  That time it was known as the Quila-E-Mubarak which meant the blessed fort. when it was built by Shah Jahan, Originally made with Lime stone and eventually started chipping off. The British Government then had the entire monument painted red, this changing its original color forever and also name changed as Red Fort.A satellite view of this fort reveals an octagonal shape.Tourist Attractions in side fort:Though there are many structures in the fort were either destroyed or badly damaged, the red fort still houses many historic places. They are1. Mumtaz Mahal:2. Khas Mahal3. Rang Mahal4. HIra Mahal5. Moti Masjid6. Hammam7. Diwan e Aam8. Naubat Khana9. Diwan e Khas10. Hayat Bajsh Bagh11. Mehrab BaghLight Show:Since year 1996 there is light show arranged inside the Red fort. Light show timings are varied season to season. But one can check the timing before visiting. It is always suggestable to plan your visit in the Evening and after visiting the fort you can witness light show which is one of the must visit attraction of Red fort. Entry ticket is 60 INR per adult, 20 INR per child on Weekdays and 80 INR per adult, 30 INR per child on weekends. Time to cover Red fort:The minimum time that one needs to see Lala Kila is around 2 hours and it may go up to 3 to 4 hours if you are planning to explore thoroughly.Timings:Morning 09:30 to Evening 04:30 all weekdays except on Monday.Entry ticket:50 INR per Indian Adults600 INR per Foreigners

Name: Kelly Johnson
Title: Old Delhi area visit
Review: Good place to visit in winter time. Very near to Chandi chowk where you can do lots of shopping.really nice place

Name: Ranjith
Title: Must See Place
Review: Red for is a must visit Place when you are at Delhi. Easy access. Bit crowded, however worth visiting

Name: SangitaMangal
Title: Must visit historic place in Delhi
Review: Very popular destination, must visit, vast place, lot of walking required, wheel chairs available on request. Beautiful historic place. Lots of stuffs to buy. Sometimes very rush, can be managed and handled better. Overall a great place. Loved the experience.

Name: Rajab
Title: Just  the hotel service was good üëç
Review: I very enjoyed the service of the hotel every things was good  so I would like to thanks Mr Tarun and Madam vaishnavi

Name: PANDEY JI
Title: World Heritage Site.
Review: Entry ticket for Indian Nationals is ‚Çπ 80.You've to walk about a kilometre or so to get to the actual fort.There are informative stone plaques in front of the monuments. It's a world heritage monument.

Name: KodoDrummer
Title: Amazing architecture & massive outer walls
Review: I spent about 2.5 hours touring the massive grounds of the Red Fort and the special museum dealing with the horrific atrocities of the British invaders/occupiers.

Name: singhasam
Title: History on a vast scale
Review: WHEN your guide tells you that the Red Fort site in New Delhi covers ten square kilometres you wonder how you are going to have the strength to get round it all.Then he tells you that most of the site is out of bounds because the Indian Army are based there and the public can only view two square kilometres.I relaxed a little at that news but by the end of my visit I was exhausted from a tremendous amount of walking and climbing up and down steps.The Red Fort really is a gigantic construction with walls 100ft high and a network of interlocking passages for defence. Work to build the fort began in 1638 and was completed in 1648Just the walk to the entrance was a taste of things to come as we passed along the base of the wall with its grassy moat ditch.Even here the legacy of Covid reared its head because once we got inside we found that all the waterways were dry, emptied on the order of the Indian Government as part of its attempts to combat Covid.It meant visitors had to imagine what the true setting would have been like with platforms for musicians surrounded by water and channels of water tinkling everywhere.There were harems, hamams, areas set aside for justice, cannons, holes for other weapons and a host of other features.To reach this rich display we had to walk through a sort of covered bazaar of stalls offerings everything from chess sets and backgammon boards to carved stone in 64 arched bays, half on each side.I particularly liked the Hall of Public Audience or Diwan-i-Am with its lovely carved stone, a marble throne area and the stunning palace area with carved marble inlaid with semi-precious stones which was truly beautiful.It is a very tiring site to visit and those going there should make sure they have bottled water with them as those sections in the open quickly become quite hot.Definitely worth a visit by anyone who is in New Delhi.

Name: Vaibhav Rathore
Title: Outstanding and incredible too....
Review: find myself so tiny in front of this gigantic monument....from where Hon'ble Prime Minister of India are addressing the citizens since 1947....I visited mueseum on Subash Chandra Bose....

Name: NVKOnTheGo
Title: Lacks tourist face-lift
Review: When we visited there was no parking near the Red Fort and had to walk 20-25 minutes in the hot sun to get to the entrance. The place could be maintained so much better. Tons of shops inside make it feel like a shopping mall!

Name: Akshay P
Title: Important historical place of great relevance
Review: This is a must visit to get a feel about history. The place is vast and has a decent exhibition which shows various exhibits, photographs and storyline about British occupation and their tyranny. The struggle for independence, particularly the 1857 struggle is nicely depictedIt would have been good if the authorities can provide audio guides in foreign langauges which can make it really interestingThe overall place could be maintained better with more signboards and explanations

Name: Swati Negi
Title: Great & memorable!
Review: Visited Red Fort today with my colleagues and our guide was a humble and kind Lalit ji. He showed us around, took pictures, made sure we were comfortable (got water bottles). I'd recommend reaching out to him if you are looking for a guide. Attached is our pic with our guide.

Name: Vinod M
Title: A fort with a view
Review: we walked by the red fort ,since it was already evening. the place is huge. and looks better than we see in the television.there are lot of tourists around.so its very difficult to take photographs in which  there will be only you and your family. there will always be strangers.since we were visiting the Agra fort, which we were told is similar to Red fort, we decided to skip visiting the interiors of this historic fort

Name: Alena B
Title: Too crowded, dirty, not maintained
Review: Although it is UNESCO, it is not worth seeing. It is dirty place, too crowded, not maintained place. Entrance fee 600 rp for foreigners.

Name: Aaditya Paudel
Title: Red Fort | Netaji Subash Marg
Review: Disclaimer: If you are not as much interested in History then you'll not find it impressive but if you are, then it is a must-visit place. Lots of historical places and architecture.

Name: Sangram Mohite
Title: Red Fort - Truly worth visiting
Review: RED FORT, DelhiA must visit for every Indian in his lifetime. seat of Mughals which saw its grandeur and very existence.Duration -2-3 hrs. Entrance Fee - INR 80/-Nearest METRO Station is Jama Masjit / Lal Quila. Walkable from both these metro stations.A very well maintained fort. if you are history buff, do book Guide.There is a private musuem inside which costs you INR 100 PPMusuem timmings are till 5PM. Hence plan accordingly. Early morning are best timings to visit

Name: URVASHI OBEROI
Title: EXCELLENT
Review: Nice heritage place & near by market is also very good for shopping , i buy lingerie from there from Sanjeev store.

Name: Lakshmi Biradar
Title: Oldest fort in Old Delhi
Review: The Red Fort which is also known as Lal Qila is a  very old historic fort in Old Delhi. Every year on 15th august the Prime minister of India hoists the flag at Red fort. It had various structures inside. The day I visited their server was down and could not book entry ticket. I saw the red fort from outside and came back. One advise plan to book the entry ticket one day before. Too crowded place.

Name: Footloose
Title: Grand and splendid
Review: Grand. Its an icon of the city and a  must see. When you see the Indian flag hoisted as you enter the place, it just make one proud. It's a huge complex with enormity to soak in so take your time. The architecture is splendid, was left speechless. Need tickets for entering. There is a museum that is worth a visit.

Name: Rajesh R Kumathekar
Title: Amazing, Inspiring & mesmerizing experience!
Review: Happy Independance Day!Got opportunity to be present at Red Fort for flag hoisting!Red fort is witness for changing India

Name: Pranati M
Title: India's pride add to your list
Review: The beautiful red fort magestically standing in the heart of Delhi. Reminds me of old British era and the way kings have given their best to protect their land. Opposite to it is chandni chowk where you can roam around in the evening. Nice and well maintained place.

Name: travellerZ6006SK
Title: Filthy crowded city
Review: Corrupt filthy surroundings..barely able to walk..vendors dogs and garbage everywhere.  Swach Bharat is not.working in most places in India which is still filthy everywhere you go

Name: Kitty B
Title: Great views
Review: Stunning place to visit, and clearly seen around the local area, lot of walking.Around the fort you can see where the British used to govern. There are many ornate carvings in the stone and the areas inside have so much detail and style. *Note the price is usually more expensive for foreigners

Name: ANUJ
Title: History to be visited
Review: If you wish to visit the history of India then start with this from our capital city RED FORT, Its like pride of our country. A must for tourists but plan during autumn to winter season otherwise Delhi whether can be a spoil sport .

Name: Ron
Title: Huge fort area
Review: The fort area is very large, but parts are still closed to public. Impressive, but not in the same league as Taj Mahal or Agra fort.

Name: Shreoshi Tarapdar
Title: Tour to Red Fort
Review: The tour was amazing , specially with the guide named , Daljeet Singh . He explained the history so well , moreover , he was friendly , kind and polite enough . The place was good . The Meena Bazaar was the most fascinating place , where you will find tax free and cheapest things . There were restaurants and museums . Though it takes a long time to see the place inside the Red Fort . Thus , one has to plan accordingly . The scenic beauty was amazing and there was a show in the evening time also . Overall , the tour was amazing .

Name: Yashu
Title: Visit at least once
Review: We were very excited to visit there.Finally we did.Nice place it will help you to feel your history.

Name: Leoni
Title: Stiflingly hot
Review: We suggest everyone to come here during spring or autumn. Just before monsoon, it was hot. There are no clean washrooms.

Name: RkRoadie
Title: Huge area needs lot of walking
Review: Red fort is the most important architecture in India. The area has two different parking lot. One can park the car at Jama Masjid parking and walk towards ticket counter or else there is parking space near to Red Fort ticket counter as well. Vehicle entry is restricted ahead of parking place which is exactly at opposite site of main entrance of Red Fort hence one need to keep walking all through the outer boundary till main entrance of Red Fort.The picturesque Red Fort can be clicked from outside itself which dont need any sort of ticket. Once you enter inside the passage passes through Chatta Bazaar where you can shop for things (only cash was accepted). Inside the main campus there are many architectural building where you can click some more pics and come out again through Chatta Bazaar. Keep your ticket safe as the authority do check it again at exit.

Name: Kashyy
Title: The beautiful Lal Killa
Review: This was my favourite architectural marvel after the Taj. Red fort or Lal Killa as it is popularly addressed is one of the most beautiful and most visit monuments in North India.

Name: Fran-Svk
Title: Worth to visit
Review: nice place of Delhi which one should visit. inside is large "park", fortunately clean. and just behind entrance is market where you can buy souvenirs.foreigners have special ticket price, 600R.inside of Red Fort are located several place which are mentioned independently here on TripAdvisor.

Name: Kanoujiya
Title: Nice
Review: Nice place to visit with family and friends.. Red fort is a pride of our nation... Being a indian i feel so proud to come every time

Name: Laura R
Title: Amazing no bags
Review: So amazing and beautiful üòç  it was greatly constructed. You can't take your bag in so leave it at the car, or you can leave it at the entrance

Name: Vlaamse_Reiziger
Title: Large compound with some buildings.
Review: The Red Fort is one of the tourist attractions of Delhi (of which there are not many). It is located in the Old part of Delhi. From the outside you only see a huge wall, but on the inside there is a 250 acres (100 hectares) compound with about 10 buildings from the Moghul times (the king who built it in 1658 also built the Taj Mahal), plus about 10 buildings built by the British in the late 1800s-early 1900s. It is worthwhile a visit, but you will be completing the visit in less than an hour. For me the most impressive part was the sheer size of the whole compound. Some practicalities:- go as early in the day as possible. Otherwise you will face loooong queues to buy the ticket, again for the security check etc- the main entrance (near Chandni Chowk) is closed (Oct2021), so you must enter from where the parking is.- be prepared to walk! First you must walk around half the compound from the entrance (parking) to the actual entrance in the buildings (buying your tickets on the way). Then, inside, there is quite a lot to walk. The place is not wheelchair friendly. - Inside the compound are quite a number of trees, which provide some nice shade (remember you are in Delhi!). - The Moghul buildings are nice but not very well restored, and due to covid, tourists are not allowed to visit the inside of some of them. The British buildings are museums but can easily be skipped: they are a mishmash of the take-over by the British, some resistance fighting, some paintings (unrelated to the site) etc. - Bring something to drink because there is no place to buy drinks (I understand one of the British buildings is being renovated to become a cafetaria)- You can hire a tour guide as you walk in (500 INR) but you can as well jot down the few things to know from a guidebook or from the web.  - Inside is a market with tourist junk.

Name: Ajantha K
Title: Tasty food
Review: Don't miss to have your food in the small roadside shop opposite to the Red fort parking area. They serve the best Aloo parathas and curries at very less price. We enjoyed our breakfast there.

Name: Dasila punit
Title: Good views and good tourist visit
Review: It's very good tourist visit at red fort old dehli. Excellent location near by metro Red fort made by mughals and near to jama masjid and Chandni Chowk  market. Red Fort is very oldest fort in India. It is situated in Delhi. This is very beautiful place . The garden is also good.

Name: Sachin Gupta
Title: Excellent location near by metro Red fort made by mughals and near to jama masjid and Chandni Chowk
Review: Excellent location near by metro Red fort made by mughals and near to jama masjid and Chandni Chowk  market

Name: skagarwal74
Title: Symbol of pride
Review: I visited Red Fort on 16th Jan. Lal Qila Metro station is the nearest and most suitable means to visit the fort.The view at the entry is mesmerising and after a few clicks, we proceeded to the left for tickets. The tickets can be done online here after scanning the bar code through paytm. It asks for name, ID number and after online payment, the ticket is generated in form of mobile barcode ticket. This is scanned on the machine at the entry gate. For visit to museums combined ticket of higher denomination must be taken.You are allowed to carry your bag after scanning.Inside you have a huge premises and after passing through the main porch you see the Indian flag flying high. Opposite you have stairs reaching to the podium from where our PM delivers his speech. When you proceed further, there are some shops, and then you have  Diwan-i-Am, Naubat Khana, Rang Mahal, Diwan-i-Khas, Moti Masjid, Mumtaz Mahal. You have 6 Museums buildings out of which one at the left extreme end is free for all. For others you must have bought the Museum ticket at the main entry itself.This Museum called Drishyakala building (Ground plus 2) is free and houses old paintings and collections.It takes atleast half a day to move around here at Red fort. Opposite the Red fort you have Chandni Chowk where you can look for shopping and food.

Name: beyondtravel
Title: Lal qila
Review: The epitome of delhi sultanate history, home to republic Day and modern national celebrations, the iconic red fort is a magnificent monument adding beauty to the locality.

Name: NOMADIC TOURIST
Title: Fort Of India
Review: 1. Red Fort is another historic monument representing the strength and pride in the country.2. This fort is a must-visit for all the travellers to experience the essence of Delhi.3. The place is well maintained and organised.4. Ticket pricing is affordable and best suitable for day trip visit along with family, friends, and group hangouts.5. The place is easily accessible by public and private transport.6. Pro Tip - Beware of overcharging for transport.

Name: pawandeep@1990
Title: Mugal fort
Review: The red fort commonly known as the lal quila is situated in delhi and was built during mughal raj in india wherein the last mughal emperor was Bahadur Shah Zafar who stayed in this fort with delhi as his territory. at every independence day the prime minister of india hoists the national flag at red fort and the parade on the republic day comes to an end at the red fort only.

Name: Saddguru Shri
Title: Pride
Review: The Red forte is pride of India. If you are planning to go Delhi, I request you kindly must visit there.

Name: Rahul G
Title: the Mughal fort
Review: nothing is there that meets the expectations. the place is in ruins. and nothing left but the architecture.

Name: Jehosh
Title: Never go in noon
Review: The most important place in Delhi to visit. The place from where PM hoists flag on every independence day.Its a really really huge place and needs minimum 3 to 4 hours to go around. As we had less time, we took photos outside the main structure( which is a popular photo spot).But if you want to get inside, it's crowded mostly and ticket is 30rs. Also please note it's a bit far from parking area too. So be prepared to walk a lot. And never prefer noons as you won't be able to handle the heat

Name: Tapanmc
Title: Red Fort Symbol of Authority
Review: Redfort  was the official residence of Mughol emperors after Emperor Shahjahan commissioned it 1638 . It walls are made of red sanstone thats why it is called Lal Killa.There are many special places to visit inside the fort like Dewan E khas ,Dewan E Aam ,Mumtaj Mohal ,Heera Mahal . All places are not open to the visitors. In the main entry there are suvenir shops

Name: S Sam
Title: Its a must visit historical place in Delhi
Review: Its a must visit historical place in Delhi. This very old construction gives light about India's prideful historical age.

Name: Amit Gupta
Title: Fort Visit
Review: Red Fort is very oldest fort in India. It is situated in Delhi. This is very beautiful place . The garden is also good.

Name: dhen
Title: One of Many Historic Sites
Review: Enjoyed our visit to the Red Fort as we did most of the historic sites in New Delhi. Very photogenic and many areas inside to explore. One of the more crowded sites we visited in Delhi which detracted a bit from the experience. Much of the interiors areas were not accessible. One of those areas I would only explore on a tour as it is difficult to reach through the crowded streets nearby.

Name: Abhinav
Title: The Important History of Delhi
Review: The place is quite good in terms of how it reflects the history of the country. A very photogenic place and lies adjacent to Chandni Chowk where you can grab Delhi's coolest authentic spicy street food. The best time to go there would be during weekdays, as on weekends there are too much of a traffic.

Name: SAROJ8585
Title: THE RED FORT
Review: The red fort is one of the famous buildings of Delhi.It is made of red sand stone.It was constructed by mughal emperor Shahjahan.Some of the notable rooms in the Red fort are the Diwan i khas,Diwan i aam etc.The world famous peacock throne was also placed here.It was taken by Nadirshah to Iran after his conquest of Delhi.

Name: Anjan Sengupta
Title: Go for 'Azadi ke Diwane' Museum
Review: There is nothing much to see in the Red Fort as most of the buildings inside just lack the charisma.Also a big portion of the fort is not accessible to the public. The newly inaugurated museum named 'Azadi ke Diwane' makes a visit t this place a bit worthy now. Its recommended for all Indians to visit this museum once for sure.

Name: Debashis T
Title: The beauty of Mughal Architect
Review: Opens through out the year except for Monday between 9:30 am to 4:30 pm with entry fee of Rs.35/- for adult. Better to book online ticket as the queue is very long before the ticket counter.Many parts of this big fort are closed now,so what took usually 2-3 hours some years before now takes around 1 to 1.30 hrs.Very much walking is needed inside it. Lush green gardens are there inside to seat.This large fort comprises multiple architectural structures inside it which is covered by the big red wall, giving its name.

Name: sanjayvora45
Title: historical
Review: Red fort is a well known landmark place in delhi. Inside the fort there are many building and pavilion to view.Much of the interior or valuable are destroyed or looted during british era war.

Name: Meander With Mer
Title: Good for a walk by... We didn't go in...
Review: The Red Fort was included in jam-packed 1 day tour we had in Delhi.  With only 1 day we unfortunately couldn't see it all, so our tour just included a walk by the exterior of the building.  While we walked the exterior our guide gave us the history of the building and if we could have seen more we would.  Even though we did not go in if you have the time I think it could be a very interesting  stop on a tour.

Name: lara
Title: MUST VISIT
Review: It was a great experience!This place is BEAUTIFUL and well maintained! This landmark comprises a large complex full of multiple architectural structures with acres of well-kept gardens in between! It is all enclosed by a huge wall, which is covered by red sand stone thus giving it its name!I visited the museum and spent 90 minutes! It felt safe and the facilities are clean. Better take a guide and buy tickets online as they are cheaper

Name: Jovial Holiday
Title: Best Monument of Delhi
Review: The Red Fort indeed forms a monument par excellence that combines the features of Persian, Timurid, and Indian architecture. You can see many historical monuments like Museums, Delhi Gate, Lahori Gate, Chhatra Chowk, Diwan-i-Aam, Naubat Khana and many more

Name: vincent1971
Title: MUST VISIT
Review: Mughal rulers made Delhi as their head quarter. So they built Red Fort in Delhi. It is covered by red sand stone. Do not miss Light & sound show in the evening. Beware of people over there. They will sell you things at a very high price

Name: Skeney57
Title: World Heritage Monument
Review: Those Mughal Emperors knew how to build great palaces ! The Red Fort dates back to the 1600's, took 7 years to build and is still in great shape. Lots of interesting history & magnificent buildings to explore and gardens & waterways that in their day would of been spectacular. Put aside several hours to do it justice.

Name: json67
Title: Must visit
Review: Red fort was built by mughal emperors.  It was the seat of power.  It is called Red fort as it has red sand stone all over. Do not miss the evening light and sound show

Name: R1chardN
Title: Incredible history but too much for one visit
Review: We went to the Red Fort as part of our Delhi City and highlights tour.  It is a UNESCO World Heritage site and is an impressive building.  It is a very large walled Fort - 2.5km around the battlements.Others on the site have commented that foreign tourists pay much more than locals for entrance but that is quite normal in India and be prepared for men and women to enter separately and to be searched.  The monument is occupied mainly by the military and the armed guards are very obvious and initially made me look twice.  There are also numerous protective metal 'shields' in very visible locations.  We were told that this is all due to the situation with Pakistan - we had not expected it and made us feel a bit on edge.Once inside the gates there is an arcade that is full of 'merchants' - this is not a good place to buy!!  There are numerous other celebratory buildings within the walls.This is a large 'site' and you need to be realistic in the amount of time you want to spend here.  Our guide suggested no more than two hours and it is easy to go into overload here.

Name: AstroBloke
Title: A magnificent structure, but...
Review: This old fort is magnificent, and represents the highs and lows of Indian history in the last few centuries.  It will take some 2-3 hours to do it justice.Why didn't I rate if a 5, then? Firstly, as a international visitor I was charged around 10 times the admission for locals.  To make matters worse, we paid extra to visit the museum inside but were not given the token signifying that we had paid.  The guard at the museum wouldn't take our word for it, and all but told us to get lost.  (The approx. one kilometre walk to/from the ticket office meant we couldn't be bothered following it up them there.) You understandably cannot take your backpacks inside the fort for security reasons, so you need to leave them in a makeshift facility where there is no advertised price, they charge whatever they can gouge out of you as you go to collect your belongings.All in all, what should have been the highlight of our stay in Delhi was somewhat spoilt by the way we were treated.

Name: Chris C
Title: A huge site !
Review: Better to pay via an app, rather than at the pay-booths, which seem to be around a kilometre away from the real entrance !Overseas tourists pay around ten times the entrance fee of Indian nationals ! Is that welcoming ?Take plenty of drinking water with you, as there is much ground to cover, within the walls, with many separate  buildings and pavilions to view ! Squirrels and well-fed stray dogs appear to co-habit, peacefully, too !The traders, inside, close to the entrance/exit, are ruthless at exploiting the most casual of interest - especially when they see you are hot and tired, and about to leave !You can easily spend 2 to 3 hours, here, and there are plenty of stone seats, (or low flat-topped walls ?) to rest tired limbs !Take your cameras !

Name: Gregory B
Title: Huge place, takes a few hours!
Review: Part of my Chaman Duggal tour. Amazing historical site. I highly recommend this place! A must for your trip to Dehli!

Name: Spencer
Title: So much history
Review: The fort is massive and the history behind it is very interesting, different areas inside and intricate buildings made it a memroable experience.

Name: TheMoni17
Title: A monument which has seen centuries of rise and fall.
Review: A beautiful and strong monument which has seen the rise and fall of Delhi several times, and is still standing witnessing the rise of India. Govt has recently installed lights and done some great uplifting work here.

Name: Steven_Teo
Title: A Bulwark
Review: Looking from outside is daunting for a would-be invader. The walls and moat were impressive structures. The inside was equally impressive. The road from the gate to the main court was meticulously planned in case of an invasion. The inside has other buildings.  It was worth the visit.

Name: Rahul Babbar
Title: Nice place for knowing about our history. Good place to spend time with family and friends.
Review: Only ticket holder can visit it. Use your mobile for download self ticket after payment online that is cost cheaper than offline ticket. Peaceful place many shows pantings and many more. Every single site has its own story. Some shows are paid also which included in ticket there are 2 type of ticket for show or not only 10 to 20 rs difference between them.

Name: WeDiscover8890
Title: Nice landmark - shame about the prices
Review: Nice attraction to walk around, disappointed how foreigners have to pay x10 the price of locals. Doesn‚Äôt seem fair at all but this seems to be common across all main landmarks in India.

Name: Richard Ludlow OBE
Title: Red Fort
Review: The fee was 600 rupees for the monument and gardens. It‚Äôs worth a visit, getting away from the busy streets. I paid 350 rupees extra to visit the museum within the grounds. As this was a barracks it focussed on the journey to independence from Britain. A thought provoking visit! I learnt a lot about the struggles the country has endured.

Name: Linda L
Title: Red Fort
Review: We went by bus to the Red Fort but didn't go in as no time.It is made of sandstone from India.It is imposing within Delhi.

Name: MAYANK
Title: TRAVEL
Review: Anything like historic places is a must visit once in your lifetime!! Though it is not that great to hang out, still one time visit is a must to the place!

Name: Sh12014
Title: Beautifully interesting
Review: We were taken by our guide who gave us the history of the fort.  A beautiful place and well worth a visit.

Name: Enkhtuya
Title: nice Fort
Review: it's a worth visiting place. very big. and  it would take whole day if you wander around, visit all the museums they have.

Name: miq
Title: Architectural masterpiece
Review: An island of piece in the middle of old Delhi chaos. Enjoy the stroll in the park, between great examples of mughal architectue and watch the playing squirrels.. :)

Name: AMDS94
Title: Very Nice Architecture
Review: The Laal Qila (Red Fort) was built in the mogul empire. It has stunning architectural views and beautiful garden walking space.Would recommend to anyone who is travelling to Delhi to see this place.

Name: Dave_Kippax
Title: Impressive building amazing architecture
Review: Visited as part of the Titan Tour, the guide was amazing, setting the seen and explaining the building and layout, including uses.  A beautifully appointed fort.  Worth a visit.

Name: Prabal Basu Roy
Title: Excellent
Review: A national pride.....very well written and explained at every point. Only the Son et Luminiare was stopped for some reason and that was disappointing as it was truly an excellent show.

Name: Alex C
Title: Interesting huge fort
Review: We went to the Red Fort as part of a guided tour. It was really interesting and had various parts to explore. I was glad we had a guide to show us around as there aren't many signs. But overall we enjoyed it.

Name: louiset809
Title: Calm in the middle of New Delhi
Review: The Red Fort is a must see in New Delhi. Right in the middle of New Delhi you walk through the entrance to acres of beautiful grounds and magnificent buildings.

Name: CWegg
Title: Disappointing inside
Review: The Red Fort is a beautiful and imposing historical landmark in Delhi. I certainly think every visitor should have a look. However, there is not much to see inside. Many interiors are closed and most of the areas you can visit are poorly maintained. I did not find this site to be worth the steep price of the foreigner admission ticket. Instead, walk around the exterior of the fort, then spend your time wandering the streets of Old Delhi. You won‚Äôt be disappointed and you‚Äôll have more money in your pocket.

Name: subuller
Title: Impressive ...
Review: This was the first of many places we visited on a recent trip to India.  It's quite something to see and well worth the visit.  The grounds are extensive and a guide is useful.

Name: Vivienne M
Title: Amazing
Review: Architecture is fantastic. Walls surround the fortress which protected the royal residence of Shah Jahan and subsequent Emperors. Very impressive.

Name: Chandan K
Title: The pride of India
Review: The red fort make by shah jahan the historical building make for ancient time my family visit and take many more selfie

Name: The Food Wanderer
Title: Architectural Marvel
Review: The Red Fort is a architectural marvel in north Delhi. You would need atleast 4 hours to completely understand and take a look at the whole structure.

Name: rae5753
Title: Red Fort Jaipur
Review: Very interesting site. Well worth the trip. A marvel of construction. Tour was great and very informative,

Name: Travel_Revival
Title: Impressive!
Review: Massive fortress walls protect the royal residence of Shah Jahan and subsequent Mughul Emperors. Much of the interior was destroyed by the British, but enough remains to give a perspective on the lavish lifestyle of the ruling Mughals. Information boards give the history of each building within the compound.

Name: ghummiwithnandini
Title: Big big
Review: That place is so big and amazing too , you need 3 to 4 hours to completely enjoy the place. there are many monuments there.

Name: sharjeelcool
Title: Good
Review: Come and visit this iconic place and I am sure you that you will be left spellbound with its beauty and massive size

Name: Ivan B
Title: Incredible
Review: Incredible inside, huge, good to have a Guide to explain all internal architecture,  places, cultures and history behind.

Name: katieko
Title: Disappointing and overpriced
Review: A real disappointment as you couldn't go into any of the buildings here - all were roped off so you just had to peer over the barriers and take a photo. Having visited many forts in our trip round India, including Agra's which we'd heard was similar, this was the only one to disappoint. Agra has far more beautiful rooms to see and you can actually wander inside them. This ended up just being a wander round a large park area, without any nice gardens, so we felt the visit was hugely overpriced.

Name: Rahul Kumar
Title: Wow
Review: It's a great architecture made buy mugals...Made of red stone which is remarkable ....Well maintained n cleaned by the authority ..,

Name: GAURAV M
Title: Mr.  Gaurav Mangla
Review: We visited the place but could see the fort only from outside. But we were to lucky to reach there in the eve. It was superb to watch the fort in the evening with all the lights ON.. I could only imagine how creative Shahajan must have been.  The Red fort and Taj Mahal both are made by him. The architecture of both the places is beyond imagination..

Name: InnaYYZ
Title: Impressive fort of Mughal Emperors
Review: Beautiful, well-maintained former residence of Mughal Emperors. Built, added to and modified over the years, this historic fort displays a few architectural styles.

Name: jjcoffman
Title: Red Fort visit in Delhi
Review: We hired a driver to take us around Delhi, before driving us to Agra. The Red Fort was one of our stops. It‚Äôs easy to get to, and you can pay to have a tuk tuk take you right up to the entrance, but the walk isn‚Äôt too far.  It‚Äôs just the hazardous air quality that can make it difficult.

Name: Ann S
Title: Make sure to take enough time when visiting
Review: We went to the Red Fort whilst on a business trip, so had no time to do our research first. Turned out to be a huge place so try to take enough time when visiting. The other reviews are true: ticket counter for non-Indians is "at the other side" so take into account that you'll have to do quite some walking.There's plenty of choice to buy souvenirs inside the Red Fort.

Name: NafeeTA
Title: Old Delhi at its Best
Review: The visit to the Red Fort will take you on a journey to Old Delhi. The fort is just beside Jama Masjid. The fort has different entry rates for Indian Citizens and Foreigners, so its best if you check out the current rates online before going. The ticketing line for foreigners is usually very small, so dont fall for scammers who tell you that they can get you in faster. The walk from the ticket counter to the actual entry gate is a bit long, you can use the tuktuk that run along this path, at Rs 10 per person. Once inside, you can opt to take a guide, there are many waiting just outside the entry gate, but be sure to bargain for the prices. The fort itself covers a vast area, and honestly if you wanted to explore it all, you would literally have to spend about 4-5 hrs. We stayed for about 2 hrs, until we got exhausted of walking and taking pictures. All together, make sure to check if the fort will be open on the days you plan to go, and check out the current prices for tickets to avoid being scammed.

Name: sujatasingh2222
Title: Beauty of Delhi
Review: The picture of oldDelhi, Red Fort is located opposite to Chandni Chowk Market.Good option to reach there is Violent line metro if you are traveling from public transport.

Name: Hungryhens123
Title: Awesome Red Fort
Review: Wow, impressive size and would recommend the government approved guide but ensure you can understand him first. A must see when going to Agra.

Name: Barbara S
Title: At last I saw the Red Fort
Review: This was my third visit to Delhi and finally I have got to the Red Fort in all its stunning glory. It is cold and smoggy at this time of year, but enjoyed the walk around the site as it was not too crowded once in the fort.
